newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Highlights of Tuesday's Commission briefing.
newsitem.headline: Highlights of Tuesday's Commission briefing.

text.p: Following are highlights of the midday briefing by the European Commission on Tuesday:
Spokesman Joao Vale de Almeida said the news release on the outcome of today's Commission meeting, apart from Agenda 2000, would be available around 1600/1400 GMT.

Spokesman Filipo di Robilant said Commissioner Emma Bonino had addressed the EP on Monday evening on action taken over illegally exported British beef. He said the Commission was still considering infringement procedures against the United Kingdom for inefficient border controls.
Di Robilant added that the UK authorities seemed fully aware of the situation and that they were willing to act.

Spokeswoman Elisabetta Olivi said the Commission was pleased with the new U.S. offer for the negotiation of the liberalisation of financial services under way at the World Trade Organisation. She said a "major step" had been made and that there was a clear will to reach a multilateral agreement.
Olivi also said there was also clear progress in Japan's offer.
The Commission released the following documents:
- IP/97/643: Belgium, France, Germany and Greece fail to comply with Community Law regarding free movement of workers and social security.
- IP/97/651: Floods in Central and Eastern Europe: European Commission to rush humanitarian aid worth 500,000 ECU.
- IP/97/653: Commission proposes a new procedure for the adoption of certain implementing measures relating to indirect taxation.
- IP/97/655: Third report on Community actions affecting tourism (1995-1996).
- IP/97/658: Commission approves the placing on the market of a test kit containing a genetically modified micro-organism.
